item.title: Meta Begins $65 Million Election Push to Advance A.I. Agenda
item.description: Meta’s biggest election investment aims to prevent state legislation that it fears could inhibit artificial intelligence development. Its spending starts this week in Texas and Illinois.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and Matt Zdun
item.category: American Technology Excellence Project (Political Action Committee)
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta is quietly supporting two new super PACs as it aims to influence the regulatory environment for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Elon Musk’s xAI Gets $3 Billion Investment From Saudi-Backed A.I. Firm
item.description: Humain, which was created by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman last year, said it made the investment just before xAI was acquired by SpaceX, Mr. Musk’s rocket company.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman with Elon Musk at a Saudi Arabia Investment forum at the Kennedy Center in Washington last year.

item.title: Uber Taking Steps to Expand Number of EV Chargers Near Its Drivers
item.description: The company said it would encourage companies that operated chargers to install them in neighborhoods where its drivers lived and work.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Spencer Platt/Getty Images
item.media:description: Drivers for Uber, Lyft and other taxi services are often the biggest users of charging stations, like this one at Kennedy International Airport.

item.title: How to Watch Free Live Television on Your Phone or Tablet
item.description: Whether by app or old-school antennas, budget-friendly options abound.
item.dc:creator: J. D. Biersdorfer
item.media:credit: J.D. Biersdorfer
item.media:description: Tubi, shown here on an iPad, is one of the many advertising-supported streaming apps that bring free live television programs to mobile devices.

item.title: Decoding the A.I. Beliefs of Anthropic and Its C.E.O., Dario Amodei
item.description: The company is at odds with the Pentagon over how its A.I. will be used. The conflict has its roots in the foundational plan for Anthropic.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The contract between Anthropic and the Pentagon, worth as much as $200 million, is at stake.

item.title: Defense Department and Anthropic Square Off in Dispute Over A.I. Safety
item.description: How artificial intelligence will be used in future battlefields is an issue that has turned increasingly political and may put Anthropic in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Defense Department and Anthropic have been negotiating a contract over A.I. use by the Pentagon.

item.title: Mark Zuckerberg Takes the Stand in Social Media Addiction Trial
item.description: Meta’s chief executive said users spent a lot of time on Instagram because of its value, as he was grilled about child safety issues in front of a jury.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg has been criticized over allegations that his company created child safety and privacy problems.

item.title: What Do A.I. Chatbots Discuss Among Themselves? We Sent One to Find Out.
item.description: We interviewed our bot about what it learned on Moltbook, the A.I.-only social network.
item.dc:creator: Eve Washington

item.title: Chatbots Are the New Influencers Brands Must Woo
item.description: Companies are realizing they can no longer simply promote themselves to potential customers. They have to win over the robots, too.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith
item.media:credit: Vincent Kilbride

item.title: With Niche Tech World References, Vibe Hopes Its Billboards Reach Start-Up Insiders
item.description: Billboards that wouldn’t make sense to people outside the tech industry have become common in the Bay Area. One company took the microtargeting game to another level.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha and Minh Connors

item.title: User Issues With X Appear to Have Resolved
item.description: The social media site was the subject of user complaints early Monday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Could an Electronic Coach Help Ski Jumpers Leap Farther?
item.description: Future Olympic prospects are testing a device that can give them corrective advice in real time as they hurtle into the air.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: More Than Ever, Videos Expose the Truth. And Cloud It, Too.
item.description: In Minneapolis, videos of the Alex Pretti killing undermined the federal government’s account. But an A.I. video of Brad Pitt shows the dangers ahead.
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: UGC/Reuters
item.media:description: A screen grab from a video showing how federal agents wrestled Alex Pretti to the ground before fatally shooting him.

item.title: Ring Ends Deal to Link Neighborhood Cameras After Backlash to Super Bowl Ad
item.description: A commercial about a lost dog being reunited with his family ignited concerns that a “Search Party” feature posed privacy risks. Ring parted ways with the tech company Flock Safety.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ring doorbell security camera on the front of a building in New York. The planned integration of those cameras to activate a search function gave rise to criticism after a Super Bowl ad.

item.title: David J. Farber, ‘Grandfather of the Internet,’ Dies at 91
item.description: A researcher, professor and federal policy adviser, he guided students who went on to do groundbreaking work in connecting the world online.
item.dc:creator: Peter Wayner

item.title: Their Secret to a Happy Marriage? A Translation App
item.description: He speaks English. She speaks Mandarin. The secret to their happy marriage: Microsoft Translator.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill and Oliver Farshi
item.media:description: David Duda and Hong Liang at their home in New Haven, Conn. Mr. Duda and Ms. Liang met in Xian, China, in the fall of 2019.

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: F.T.C. Chair Warns Apple Against Bias in Apple News
item.description: Andrew Ferguson of the F.T.C. said in a letter to Apple that it might be violating consumer protection law by stifling conservative speech in its news aggregation service.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Trump-appointed leaders of federal agencies have been using consumer protection laws to punish media and tech companies for perceived left-leaning bias.

item.title: ‘Something Big Is Happening’ + A.I. Rocks the Romance Novel Industry + One Good Thing
item.description: “I do think we are reaching an inflection point in people’s feelings and senses about A.I. and where it’s going.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Vjeran Pavic, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Getty Images

item.title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
item.description: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Kalley Huang and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The maker of Meta’s smart glasses said it sold more than seven million pairs last year.

item.title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
item.description: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters blocked a road last month in Tehran. Iran is using facial recognition and phone data to track and detain people involved in political opposition activities.

item.title: Anthropic Is Valued at $380 Billion in New Funding Round
item.description: The artificial intelligence start-up raised another $30 billion, and its valuation more than doubled since its last funding round in September.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthropic was founded by Dario Amodei, right, and his sister, Daniela Amodei, who had parted ways with OpenAI.

item.title: Why Tech Giants Are Accused of Causing Social Media Addiction
item.description: In a series of landmark trials, plaintiffs are alleging that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products. Our technology reporter Cecilia Kang describes what’s at stake for tech giants and social media users.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang, Christina Thornell, Laura Salaberry, Nikolay Nikolov and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Gail Slater Leaves Role as Justice Dept.’s Antitrust Chief
item.description: Her departure follows months of mounting tension over her division’s work to determine whether companies violated antitrust laws.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abigail Slater was in the job as assistant attorney general for the antitrust division for roughly a year, after her confirmation in March.

item.title: Anthropic Donates $20 Million to Super PAC Operation to Counter OpenAI
item.description: Anthropic and OpenAI now have their own well-funded political groups that will square off in the midterm elections over artificial intelligence safety and regulation.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, a co-founder and chief executive of Anthropic, formerly worked at OpenAI.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.description: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
